description: From New Latin tentāculum, from tentō. Doublet of tentaculum.

entries.meaning: An elongated, boneless, flexible organ or limb of some animals, such as the octopus and squid.
examples: The body was small, but fitted with two bunches of prehensile organs, like long tentacles, immediately under the mouth.

entries.meaning: (botany) One of the glandular hairs on the leaves of certain insectivorous plants.

examples: the tentacles of the criminal underworld

entries.meaning: (UK, military, historical) An officer employed to drive out to troops and transmit back requests for support via a special radio link.
examples: A joint RAF/Army staffed Air Support Control (ASC) headquarters was established at each army corps and each armoured division, linked to the forward brigades by a 'tentacle' equipped with two-way wireless telegraphy.

verbs.description: tentacle (third-person singular simple present tentacles, present participle tentacling, simple past and past participle tentacled)
